sections: In August, clean water stopped flowing from residents‚Äô taps in Jackson, Mississippi. The crisis lasted more than six weeks, leaving

without a consistent source of safe water. The catastrophe can be traced back to a decision by a credit ratings agency four years ago that massively inflated the city‚Äôs borrowing costs for infrastructure improvements, most notably for its water and sewer system.
In 2018, ratings analysts at Moody‚Äôs Investor Service ‚Äî a credit rating agency with a
‚Äî downgraded Jackson‚Äôs bond rating to a junk status,
in part the ‚Äúlow wealth and income indicators of residents.‚Äù The decision happened even though Jackson has never defaulted on its debt.

Moody‚Äôs move jacked up the price of borrowing for Jackson, costing the cash-strapped city between $2 and $4 million per year in additional debt service costs ‚Äî a massive financial roadblock to officials‚Äô plans to fix the municipality‚Äôs aging water system. And since the state of Mississippi and the federal government refused to use their powers to address the city‚Äôs infrastructure problems, that meant Jackson was essentially powerless to stop the impending catastrophe.

The situation underscores how Wall Street works to prevent governments from fixing their public works and contributing to an infrastructure crisis nationwide. Such actions by ratings agencies are particularly harmful in majority Black and Brown areas like Jackson, which have tight budgets and often receive minimal federal support.

All major ‚Äî and most minor ‚Äî cities, states, school, and utility districts take on debt to pay for infrastructure improvements. That debt is issued as bonds, which are agreements to pay back loans at a set interest rate. Bondholders are typically wealthy residents of the state where the bonds were issued who are seeking to accrue tax advantages, banks, insurance companies, and mutual funds.

To determine creditworthiness for this debt, bond ratings agencies give state and municipal governments a credit rating, based on factors like the community‚Äôs existing debt load and its current pension obligations. When the rating is lower, the debt is considered higher risk, and the interest rate to pay back the loans increases substantially.

Historically, the lowest possible bond ratings have been reserved for Jackson, Puerto Rico, American Samoa, Detroit, and other places long plagued by systemic disinvestment ‚Äî meaning that it becomes almost impossible for these communities to finance their way out of their infrastructure crises.
‚ÄúThe practices of the ratings agencies are often extremely racist,‚Äù Brittany Alston, research director at the Action Center on Race and the Economy (ACRE), told

that showed that all the cities at the bottom of the ratings scale have been majority-minority. As I‚Äôve been monitoring the reporting, I‚Äôve noted how the local government is characterized, I‚Äôve heard the term ‚Äòmismanagement‚Äô multiple times.‚Äù

Meanwhile, Jackson has faced significant challenges. A freeze in November 2021 that caused the city to lose potable water was the canary in the coal mine, said Catherine Robinson, a community organizer based in Jackson.
‚ÄúFor me, when the Jackson water crisis first hit in November 2021, my mom had just had a stroke,‚Äù Robinson told

There is an entrenched racial component to this state of affairs. Mississippi‚Äôs leadership ‚Äî every statewide official, the Speaker of the House and the President Pro Tempore of the state Senate, and both U.S. Senators ‚Äî have been white since the Reconstruction era ended 140 years ago, despite the state being 37 percent Black.
In an analysis of five million bonds issued to cities in the municipal bond market between 1970 and 2014, economic historian C.S. Ponder at Florida State University
that majority-Black cities are categorically charged higher interest rates to build basic infrastructure for water systems and sewage.
The same applies to Moody‚Äôs. The firm is very disconnected from life on the ground in Jackson. Moody‚Äôs CEO Rob Fauber earned
on stock buybacks over the past decade, using the capital of the company to drive up the stock.

Two of the largest municipal bankruptcies in U.S. history have been filed by majority-Black urban areas ‚Äî Detroit, Michigan, and Jefferson County (Birmingham), Alabama ‚Äî whose water systems were made targets of financial extraction. In both places, the federal government mandated upgrades to their water and sewage systems without providing funding to do so, creating roughly $5.7 billion in debt for Detroit and $3.3 billion for Jefferson County on the municipal bond market.

At the same time, Moody‚Äôs and other agencies often rated many states and municipalities with far lower ratings ‚Äî even though they had much lower probability of default, due to the unlimited taxing power of states and municipalities, as well as harsh consequences for politicians that allow defaults.
